newsitem.title: USA: NBA BASKETBALL-ROCKETS' OLAJUWON RETURNS, SCORES 16 POINTS IN WIN.
newsitem.headline: NBA BASKETBALL-ROCKETS' OLAJUWON RETURNS, SCORES 16 POINTS IN WIN.

text.p: Houston Rockets All-Star centre Hakeem Olajuwon, sidelined for the second time this season with an irregular heartbeat, was back in the lineup Wednesday night and scored 16 points in a win over the Boston Celtics.
"I feel normal. I was winded, but that's part of the game," said Olajuwon. "I'm healthy, but I need to get more minutes to get into better shape."
The Nigerian-born superstar centre also had seven rebounds and five blocks in 40 minutes, helping Houston (16-2) to its sixth straight home win, 94-89.

Olajuwon, 33, was released from a Houston hospital Monday morning after being treated for a recurrence of atrial fibrillation. Earlier in the day, he had undergone an electrical cardioversion, which returned his cardiac rate to a normal rhythm.
Olajuwon was admitted to Houston's Methodist Hospital the day before for the second time this season.

Olajuwon had 34 points and 17 rebounds in Houston's 103-99 win at Washington on Saturday night. But he said he felt "funny" when he returned to the team hotel after the game and flew to Houston the following morning.

Olajuwon also was admitted to Methodist Hospital after a November 19 game against the Minnesota Timberwolves. He underwent a exercise stress test and an echocardiogram. Both were normal and Olajuwon was released two days later.
He rested for a week and missed three games, all Houston wins. On his return, he scored 21 points in a 102-101 overtime victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.
Olajuwon missed seven games early in the 1991-92 season due to similar heartrate problems.

Olajuwon is an 11-time All-Star who won the Most Valuable Player Award in 1994 and led the Rockets to consecutive NBA championships in 1994 and 1995. He was a member of the U.S. Olympic gold medal team in Atlanta this summer.
